Hoover, Murtaugh and three other agents are listening toa TAPE RECORDING of Dr. King:
(on tape) . The efforts by the FBI to destroy our movement by peddling gossip about my sex life must be exposed.
(on tape) You cannot do this, Martin. It's suicide.
(on tape) We can weather any storm. I must make a public confession even if it means that the Movement goes on without me.
(on tape) There is no Movement without you.
(on tape; laughing) There'd better be. Anyway, I appreciate your counsel, but my mind is made up. Murtaugh rises and lunges out of the room.
Murtaugh turns away from Jeff, as if ashamed by what he remembers so clearly.  86.
King was different than the others. Simple character assassination wouldn't be enough to stop him.
Murtaugh and several OTHER AGENTS are seated in chairs in front of Hoover's desk. They bend forward like slaves waiting for their master's pronouncement
What hotel is King staying in?
In Memphis, sir?
Yes, for goodness sake!

Rivermont. Here's a photograph, sir The Agent places a BLOW-UP of the Holiday Inn Rivermont o easel. The photo, taken from a distance, shows the isolat of the large structure. Hoover shakes his head negatively
No good. Get him out of there.
Well, sir, we have a plan that --
Let me hear it.
We thought of a campaign in the news media to point out that King wants to stay in a luxury white hotel while there are Negro-owned hotels that are suffering for lack of business.
Good. Wants to conduct a "lay-in" there. Hoover smiles slightly, the others follow suit.  87.
(continuing) What Negro motels offer the best opportunity?
We think the Lorraine Motel, sir. The Second Agent places a BLOW-UP of the Lorraine Motel o the easel.
What's across the street from it?
There's an embankment --
A bank?
Sorry, sir, I meant to say an embankment -- a cliff --
I know what an embankment is!
On top of the, uh, embankment are some rooming houses and at the corner is a fire station.
They have Negro firemen there?
We'll find that out, sir.
Well, what's the plan to get him into the Negro motel?

We have prepared editorials that will be placed with sympathetic media outlets. A cooperative Senator might even be persuaded to read the release into the record. The Third Agent passes the speech.  88.
Let me see it... "This self- seeking rabble rouser..." As Hoover reads the speech, overlap Jeff.
CLOSE ON a 1968 Memphis newspaper editorial calling for K to stay at the Lorraine, which Jeff holds in his hands.
(reading) ",... rabble rouser will not share the squalor of his followers. Instead, he will be conducting a lay-in at a posh hotel..." Jeff sets the clipping down.
We packed the papers with editorials. Finally King cancelled his reservations at the Holiday Inn and booked rooms at the Lorraine Motel... And it was built like a shooting gallery...
Jesus...
Strange thing was, the King party was originally booked on the ground floor in the back...
A DARK-SKINNED MAN of East Indian appearance walks toward manager's office.

...The motel owner said that a man came by the office and asked that the King party be moved to the second floor, to room 306. The man knocks on the Manager's door. A black woman opens the door and listens to the man's instructions.  89.
(continuing) No one connected with SCLC knows who that man was.
Jeff sits quietly.
That last night, King went to speak at a church. His regular driver, Solomon Jones, drove him. I was on surveillance outside the church.
Murtaugh sits in his unmarked FBI car. Detective Redditt sits in his unmarked MPD car, across the street. Each is conducting surveillance. Rain pours down.
It was pouring rain... From the church come SHOUTS of "AMEN." THUNDER.

"... Well, I don't know what will happen now. We've got some difficult days ahead. But it doesn't matter with me now. Because I've been to the mountain top. And I don't mind. Like anybody, I would like to live a long life. Longevity has its place. But I'm not concerned about that now. I just want to do God's will. And He's allowed me to go up to the mountain. And I've looked over."
The heartbreaking last oration of MLK reaches out to the street, as do SOUNDS of the CONGREGATION... RAIN and THUN Murtaugh and Redditt sit in their separate vehicles.  90.
(continuing) "... and I've seen the Promised Land. I may not get there with you. But I want you to know tonight, that we, as a people, will get to the Promised Land!..."
Did Hoover have him killed?

He wanted him dead. I don't know if he ordered the killing. But I know he did nothing to stop it. (overwhelmed) They hated him. And they never stopped, not even after he was dead. That's why there was no real investigation. Our Security Squad was assigned by Hoover to destroy King's legacy, to destroy his widow's reputation...
Would you testify to that?
I'll say what I know. But if you want all the answers, you'll have to subpoena the files. All the files.
The setting sun casts erie shadows. Jeff and Lawson walk the embankment just below the room where Grace once lived
Did he seem credible?
You'll never find a better witness than Arthur Murtaugh. He has notes, a good memory, anda conscience. And he has guts.  91. The Reverend looks at his protege, his smile matures into low laugh.
And so do you. Jeff looks up at the bathroom window of the rooming house (the room from which Ray supposedly fired the shot).
(continuing) That's the window where James Earl Ray supposedly perched on a bathtub and shot King.
Looks like a clear shot.
It's a question of tense.
What?
It's a clear shot now. But was it a clear shot on April 4th, 1968?
Close On a blur of black and white images. The WHIRRING sound of a microfiche machine is evident. The scrolling images slow and finally stop.

Bent over the machine. One image has caught his eye: A black and white photograph of the Rooming House as viewed from the Lorraine. Trees and bushes grow on the embankmen obscuring the sightline from the bathroom.
God bless the Associated Press. This image was taken March 29, a week before the shooting.
Look at that tree. Jeff makes some notes and focuses on a short article, whi Lawson pours over files.  92.
Listen to this. (he starts reading) Press Scimitar. Kay Pitnam Black. "On the advice of former Mayor Bill Ingram, I went to the rooming house the morning after the assassination.
A city maintenance crew is working with mowers and chain saws.
A city maintenance crew was cutting down the bushes on the embankment..." Kay Black is across the street, a notepad in her hands.
Why'd the cops let them destroy a crime scene? Jeff doesn't respond. He is reloading the machine and searching for something. Finding it, he turns to Lawson.
Did you ever hear of a reporter for the New York Times named Caldwell?
Earl Caldwell. There weren't many black reporters working for The Times back then.
(reading) "I was staying in Room 215...

EARL CALDWELL, black, thirtysomething, stands in the door of Room 215 on the ground level of the Lorraine.  93. He's enjoying the evening breeze. An explosive SOUND. Caldwell is startled. He turns and looks across Mulberry Street.
. After the shot, I looked up to see a white male, dressed in coveralls in the bushes...
An area of brush surrounds the sloping area at the rear o the rooming house. A white male wearing coveralls is crouched in the bushes. There is no gun evident.

(continuing) ...A black sedan drove directly in front of me, cutting off my view. The man vanished over the embankment. The sedan kept moving, back and forth... Caldwell's line of sight is blurred by a black sedan that passes frantically back and forth in front of the motel. Tires SQUEAL. Caldwell looks at the car, then back to the bushes. The man is gone.
Lawson reloads the machine.
Caldwell wrote the story, but neither the Memphis PD nor the FBI ever questioned him.
My friend, James Orange, saw the same thing. They never questioned him, either. Lawson spins the control. Zeroes in on something.
(continuing) Look at this. CLOSE-UP: A black and white image of four men kneeling on balcony, pointing.  94.
I've seen that picture before.
It was taken seconds after the assasSination. Notice the guy on the end? Next to Ralph Abernathy. His name's Marrell McCollough.
Never heard of him.

I'm not surprised. Even Abernathy didn't know who he was. (Jeff is puzzled) McCollough led a group of militants. Called themselves "The Invaders". After the shooting, word started to leak out that McCollough was really an undercover cop.
Where is he now?
Rumor is he works for the CIA.
We need proof, not rumors. Where's the phone? Jeff gets up and starts to walk away. Lawson follows.
Jeff cradles the phone to his ear. Lawson stands to one s
(into phone) Operator, I need the area code for Langley, Virginia.
Establish the sprawling headquarters.  95.

(into phone) Marrell McCollough, please. (he waits) Mr. McCollough, My name is Jeff Jenkins. I'd like to ask you a few questions about the King assassination... CLICK. The phone goes dead. But Jeff has the confirmation
He actually answered?

Yep. Your militant Invader is moving up in the world. (sits back) So, if the shot didn't come from the rooming house... if the man Grace saw was just a decoy, if the gun he dropped was just a plant... why did Ray plead guilty?
Maybe it's time we try to talk to him. The SOUND of a W engine comes up.
Lawson is driving his bug. Gospel music plays on his radi Jeff sits beside him.
You think Ray was involved? Jim, with humor and a kind of preacher's rhythm, sets up question and response as if for the congregation.
Let's see what he could have done. Did Ray dismantle the police protection? I need a witness.
No. That was Mr. Holloman.
Say, Hallelujah. Did Ray saw down the trees? I need a witness.  96.
I can bear witness, brother. No, sir!
Say, Hallelujah.
(seriously) Did Ray fire the shot? I needa witness.
No way, brother. Ray was a bumbling burglar, not a marksman. If he was part of a plot, it's not likely he would have been the triggerman.
But Ray would be a perfect fallguy.
Say Amen, brother.
Amen.
The Brushy Mountain Penitentiary Entrance Gate just ahead

There is a steel table with four chairs. There are bars o the windows and the light spills through in patterns. JAM EARL RAY is seated at the table. He is now almost fifty y old. He speaks in a soft twang. Jeff is focusing on Ray through a VIDEO CAMERA. Lawson has files in front of him.
Mr. Ray, why did you plead guilty, if you now say you're innocent?
I had to. But I told the Judge that I would not agree that there was no conspiracy.
Why did you have to plead guilty?  97.
Did you ever see the cell in Memphis, where they kept me for eight months?

The cell is brightly lit, painted stark white. Two guards are stationed outside the cell. Television cameras are focused on Ray and are monitored in a control room by two other guards. Banks of hot lights focus on him.

Eight months. They never turned out the lights. Day or night. One of the guards, he had a nervous breakdown. I thought it was going to kill me... INTERCUT Ray suffering in jail cell, 1968; and on the monitor.
(continuing) One day, this big-shot lawyer came in. He was so full of himself, he could strut sittin' down.
PERCY FOREMAN, the famous Texas defense lawyer, talks to
You know me?
